title: Clash of the Titans: Flanders vs Roubaix Big Ride
content:

Clash of the Titans: Flanders vs Roubaix Big Ride

Whenever anyone returns from their first trip to ride the short, steep, cobbled hills made famous by the Tour of Flanders, it’s obligatory for them to point out how close together everything is.

In the space of about 40 square kilometres it is possible to tick off dozens of classic bergs and still miss out on enough that you have to start planning for a return trip. 

What also comes as a bit of surprise is how many of Belgium’s one-day races take place in this confined corner of the country.

From Oudenaarde, a pretty market town that serves as the finish of the Tour of Flanders, it’s possible to criss-cross the courses of Omloop Het Nieuwsblad, E3 Saxo Classic (previously known as E3 Harelbeke), Dwars door Vlaanderen and the Ronde van Vlaanderen itself, among others. Plus, just 35km southwest of Oudenaarde lies that other icon of the spring Classics: the city of Roubaix.

This gave us an idea. It must be possible to stitch together a route that takes in the best bits of those two great Monuments – the Tour of Flanders and Paris-Roubaix – in a single ride.

So, with a little help from our friends at Cycling in Flanders, we plotted a wiggly course that would take us from the Centrum Ronde van Vlaanderen, a museum-cum-cafe-cum-experience centre in Oudenaarde, to the hallowed velodrome in Roubaix, with lots and lots of cobbles along the way.

Ice and bergs

A ride of 98km with 905m of climbing may not sound like much of a challenge. However, once you factor in temperatures hovering around freezing, a dump of rain the night before and a weak February sun that never seems to get up above the horizon, you’ve got the makings of a memorable day on the bike. 

With our breath hanging in the air, my ride partner Dries and I roll out of town along the old railway line that has long since been converted into a smooth cycle path.

Dries is a seasoned cobble guru who works for Cycling in Flanders and knows these roads like the back of his cycling mitts, so I merely have to follow his lead. Our first appointment, just a few clicks from Oudenaarde, is with the Koppenberg. As warm-ups go, it’s a beauty. 

There’s not much I can write about the Koppenberg that hasn’t already been written. It’s steep – 22% at its maximum – its cobbles are unevenly sized and spaced, and its location (cut in between two high banks with a canopy of trees above) ensures those stones are often greasy and slippery.

It was here in 1987 that Danish rider Jesper Skibby was knocked off his bike by the commissaire’s car, which almost crushed him in the driver’s desperation to get away from the encroaching peloton.

In short, it’s a brute wholly deserving of its reputation. It has me reaching for the magic button of my Classified hub and shifting to my largest sprockets almost immediately. 

The reward for grinding up the Koppenberg’s 600 metres is a surprisingly panoramic vista across the misty hills of the Vlaams Ardennen and a fun, twisting descent. At this point, we’re still only 2km from the centre of Oudenaarde.

A hop across the N60 and we’re onto a 2.5km extended section of cobbles that links the flat Mariaborrestraat to the draggy Steenbeekdries climb before sending us down the other side on the thrilling cobbled descent of the Stationberg.

The sting in the tail of this descent is a switchback with a railway crossing at its apex to test my bike-handling skills. 

Oude you think you are?

The next big name on our list is the Taaienberg. With a maximum gradient of 15% and an attractive ‘cheat’ option of a rain gutter on its right-hand side, the Taaienberg is entwined with the legacy of Tom Boonen.

‘Tommeke’ would use the Taaienberg to test his early spring form every year with an attack here in Omloop Het Nieuwsblad (one of the very few Classics he never won).

This annual tradition became such a part of Flemish cycling culture that a statue of his legs has recently been unveiled at the top. Attacking, however, is not an option for me. Instead, I rock and grind while staring at Dries’s rear wheel. 

Over the top, and after contesting the narrow, twisting descent down into Ronse (twice host of the Road Race World Championships), we take in the cobbles of the Oude Kruisberg and the underestimated Hotondberg, crossing over into yet another of the steep-sided valleys that make up the Vlaams Ardennen. 

This brief detour not only adds some climbing metres but drops us off, after a fast, chilly downhill into Berchem, at the foot of the main event of the Belgian half of our classic adventure: the Oude Kwaremont.

The longest cobbled climb of the region, it’s also the centrepiece of the modern Ronde. The current route of the pro race climbs the Kwaremont three times, once as prologue, once to mark the start of the finale and a final time with just 12km of racing until the finish. 

This legend has seen it all, from Eddy Merckx powering away from his rivals, to Peter Sagan crashing after hooking a spectator’s jacket on his bars. It’s one of those roads where you can feel the history hanging in the misty air.

It starts with a narrow, gently rising paved section that meanders between the fields: Wout van Aert found himself unceremoniously dumped in a ditch after getting out of position on the first ascent here a couple of years ago. 

Next comes the Kwaremont proper. It’s not the steepest climb in the region by any stretch, but the cobbles here get used by cars more than most and are uneven and spread out, making it more challenging than its gradient would suggest.

It’s vital to pick your line, as changing direction costs precious momentum. Predictably, the worst-surfaced and steepest sections coincide, with a 20m patch of stones that look as if they were thrown down with a shovel.

Passing through the town square, I can almost hear the rows of spectators, feel the TV helicopter hovering overhead and smell the hot dogs… it’s worth an extra gear. 

Opposites attract

If the Kwaremont is the jab, the Paterberg is the left hook. With less than 2km between them, my heart rate has barely started to drop before I begin climbing again. Where the Kwaremont is long and steady, the Paterberg is short and brutally steep.

It’s only 350m long but averages just under 15% and tops out at 21%. What’s more, a 90° right-hand bend at its base ensures it’s impossible to carry any speed or momentum into the climb. Mercifully, it’s over quickly.

The crest of the Paterberg signals the point where we start to leave the bergs behind and head for the French border. We rejoin the cycle path for a short stretch before climbing up the Kluisberg, the point where we cross from Flanders into Wallonia and the primary language switches from Dutch to French.

The next 30km section is really just to connect the Flanders and Roubaix portions of our ride, but it still takes in some pleasant roads, passing through pretty villages and skirting the highest point in the region: the Mont Saint Aubert just outside Tournai.

As we ride, I detect a distinct shift in the landscape. The narrow valleys of the Flemish Ardennes give way to open, sodden fields and views that go on forever. Not that there’s actually much to see. 

I don’t feel any sense of boredom, however, because as we near the French border I know what’s coming and I have a rising feeling of excitement mixed with a tinge of fear.

Just a few hundred metres after we cross into France we’ll be thrown onto one of the most untamed and notorious cobbled sectors of the whole Paris-Roubaix race: Carrefour de l’Arbre.

Bump and grind

As we approach the Carrefour there’s a blur of black and yellow as a rider in full Jumbo-Visma kit speeds past. Its Coryn Labecki, winner of the 2017 Tour of Flanders, and she’s here to recon the course ahead of the Classics season. It’s a reminder that with very little effort we could extend this route to take in at least three more sectors for less than an extra 20km. 

As we watch Labecki disappear around a left hander with full commitment and no loss of speed, Dries and I look at each other and launch ourselves onto the cobbles.

The first part of the sector is slick with mud and the deep gaps between the stones are filled with water. This is Roubaix in its purest form, ruthlessly slippy from all the wet dirt deposited by the tractors that use these roads.

The advice you always hear from old hands is to stay on the crown of the cobbles, where it should be less broken up. That advice goes out the window when the crown is reduced to a razor-sharp ridge covered in grass and dirt.

I try my best to pick my line but really I’m just pedalling as hard as I can, hanging on for dear life and hoping to heaven that I don’t feel the sudden lurch of my wheels slipping from under me. A group of around 20 walkers parts as we approach, and they shout encouragement when we pass.

The transition onto a wide, pristinely surfaced route nationale is strangely jarring. The absence of vibration provokes the suspicion that something must be wrong with my bike. Still, there’s no time to check because a left-hand bend leads us straight onto the next sector at Gruson. 

After the Carrefour de l’Arbre, these cobbles seem tame by comparison, although they’re still challenging and I can feel the juddering going right through my bones.

After about 1km, a sharp right turn at the end takes us back onto tarmac and a few kilometres of smoothness to prepare for the ride’s last real challenge: the recently refurbished pavé at Hem. 

The last blast

The cobbles of this penultimate sector are large with big gaps between them, but they’re still in better shape than they were a couple of years ago, before the sector was re-laid.

At the same time, a bike path was installed alongside the cobbles, but we resist the temptation to move onto the smoother surface. The recently erected monument to Paris-Roubaix on this sector provides the perfect excuse for a breather and a photo opportunity. 

The main challenge of Hem is its length and the fact it seems to be busier with traffic than almost anywhere else on the route. Afterwards, however, it’s plain sailing through the outskirts of Roubaix towards the famous velodrome.

Before that comes the ceremonial (and often missed) final section of gentle cobbles that stretches for 200m and features the names of every winner laid into the road. We spend a few minutes picking out our favourites (Sean Kelly, thanks for asking). 

The velodrome itself is, officially, a public park. This means that anyone should be able to access the track on any day of the year for the regulation lap-and-a-half. There are no cameras, no cheering crowds, no screens, only a small gaggle of teenagers smoking.

There is, however, a magic about the place that can’t be denied. After a day spent sampling the highlights of two of the biggest races in the pro calendar, this is the only place our ride could have ended. 

Cycling in Flanders

The name says it all

If you want to know the most iconic places to ride in Flanders – with free guides and free downloadable GPX routes – then the Cycling in Flanders website is for you.

It lists every berg and cobblestone road in the region then bundles them into dozens of different rides, from the ‘easy’ 80km Blue Loop (Kwaremont, Paterberg, Koppenberg, Taaienberg, Kruisberg and Hotondberg anyone?) to the 180km Spartacus (too many bergs to list). It even has this ride.

Cycling in Flanders also set up the Flandrien Challenge, a self-initiated, self-supported ride that takes on 59 bergs spread over three days.

The resources are all free, with the challenge recorded through Strava. Complete all the segments and Cycling in Flanders will engrave your name on a cobblestone and put it in the wall at the Tour of Flanders Museum. See cyclinginflanders.cc for more information.

The rider’s ride

Jaegher FL.S Interceptor 1934, price on enquiry, jaegher.be 

If you’re going to ride in Flanders, what better than a bike built in Flanders specifically to take on the kind of roads that feature in the Tour of Flanders? Jaegher specialises in custom steel bikes, which means that each frame can be tailored to the needs of the rider, and while this one wasn’t built for me, it suited my Flanders/Roubaix ride perfectly.

The Interceptor is a road bike, but this one is nudging towards gravel territory with a long wheelbase for stability, 32mm tyres (with space for up to 40mm) and a 1x Shimano Di2 GRX groupset.

The added extra here is the Classified shifting setup, which houses a two-speed gear system in the rear hub that replicates the gear ratios of a two-chainring setup but without the need for a front derailleur.

It functioned flawlessly throughout the ride and I was thankful for the extra gears on the region’s steep bergs – the ability to shift under high load proved particularly useful.

All in all, the Jaegher Interceptor is an exciting blend of the traditional and the hi-tech.

How we did it

Travel

Eurostar is finally running a bike service again, which makes getting to Oundenaarde from London St Pancras a cinch – just over three hours door-to-door with a change at Brussel-Zuid/Midi. Prices from £107e/w.

Accommodation

We stayed at the Leopold Hotel in Oudenaarde, the start of this ride and a charming town to boot. It’s all gothic buildings, cobbles and pubs, plus it’s home to the Tour of Flanders Museum. Double or twin rooms from £105pn. See leopoldhoteloudenaarde.com for details.

Thanks

Huge thanks to Dries Verclyte and his colleagues at Cycling in Flanders for making this ride happen, and to Dries for guiding and riding on the day. Cycling in Flanders is a useful free resource for planning rides in the region. See cyclinginflanders.cc.
